title: Pitch deck outline for Aerospace Seed startups
summary: Aerospace seed pitch decks must balance technical credibility with commercial vision. Investors evaluate both your technology depth and business acumen. Lead with your unique technical insight, demonstrate market understanding, and show a realistic path through the long development journey. Pitchchat turns your deck into an interactive pitch room for investors.

sections.title: Technical Vision
sections.goal: Hook with your unique technical insight and its implications
sections.guidance: Open with the technical breakthrough or approach that enables your company. Make it accessible—investors may not be aerospace engineers. Show what's newly possible because of your innovation. This should feel like a genuine technical insight, not a business opportunity dressed in engineering language.

sections.title: Market Opportunity
sections.goal: Frame the problem you're solving and market size
sections.guidance: Size your market bottom-up: specific customer segments, their budgets, your addressable portion. Avoid trillion-dollar space economy claims. Show the pain point: what's impossible, expensive, or difficult today that your solution addresses. Include evidence of market demand: RFIs, customer conversations, or government program priorities.

sections.title: Solution & Technology
sections.goal: Explain your technical approach and current development status
sections.guidance: Present your technology with appropriate technical depth. Include your current TRL/MRL with evidence. Show development roadmap: what you've built, what's next, key risk reduction milestones. Use diagrams and specifications that demonstrate engineering rigor. Address technical risks and mitigation strategies.

sections.title: Regulatory & Compliance
sections.goal: Demonstrate you understand and can navigate the regulatory landscape
sections.guidance: Map the regulatory requirements for your product: FAA, FCC, NOAA, export controls. Show your compliance strategy and timeline. If you've had regulatory engagement, highlight it. This slide demonstrates you understand aerospace complexity and have a realistic path to market.

sections.title: Competitive Landscape
sections.goal: Position against incumbents and other startups
sections.guidance: Honest competitive analysis including well-funded competitors and primes. Show differentiation on axes that matter: cost, capability, timeline, or market segment. Acknowledge strong competitors while articulating your wedge. Include barriers to entry you're building.

sections.title: Business Model
sections.guidance: Aerospace business models vary: hardware sales, services, government contracts, data/analytics. Present your model with realistic unit economics. Show pricing benchmarks from comparable products. Address margin trajectory as you scale. Include revenue timing—when does meaningful revenue begin?

sections.title: Go-to-Market Strategy
sections.goal: Show your path to first customers and scale
sections.guidance: Map your GTM approach: government vs. commercial focus, direct vs. channel sales, geographic priorities. For government: SBIR pathway, prime contractor relationships, specific programs you're targeting. For commercial: customer pipeline, pilot programs, partnership strategy. Show you understand aerospace sales cycles.

sections.title: Team
sections.goal: Demonstrate aerospace expertise and startup capability
sections.guidance: Aerospace teams need technical depth and industry experience. Highlight relevant backgrounds: prior aerospace companies, government agencies, academic research. Show advisors who fill gaps. Address key hires you need and recruiting strategy. This is critical for aerospace credibility.

sections.title: Traction & Milestones
sections.goal: Show progress and define success metrics
sections.guidance: Present what you've accomplished: technical demonstrations, customer conversations, government funding, partnerships. Define next 12-18 month milestones with realistic timelines. Include non-dilutive funding applications and status. Show momentum despite early stage.

sections.title: Funding Plan
sections.goal: Lay out capital needs and use of funds
sections.guidance: Present your raise amount and specific use of funds. Show milestones this capital achieves. Include total capital path estimate to commercial operations. Reference non-dilutive funding strategy. Show capital efficiency thinking—aerospace investors appreciate teams who stretch dollars.
